question.p: One hundred draws are made at random with replacement from a box with ninety-nine tickets marked $\fbox{0}$ and one ticket marked $\fbox{1}$. True or false, and explain:

ol.li: The sum will be around 1, give or take 1 or so.
There is about a 68% chance that the sum will be in the range 0 to 2.

question.p: Now, suppose that instead of drawing 100 draws from this box with replacement, you draw 10,000 times with replacement. True or false, and explain:

ol.li: The sum will be around 100, give or take 10 or so.
There is about a 68% chance that the sum will be in the range 90 to 110.

solution.p: If you draw $n$ times from the box, the SE of the sum is $\sqrt{n} \times \sqrt{\frac{1}{100}\cdot\frac{99}{100}}$. So when you draw 100 times, the SE is 0.995, and when you draw 10,000 times, the SE is 9.95. And of course, the expected value of the sum is $n \cdot 1/100$, so you expect the sum to be 1 and 100 when you draw 100 and 10000 times, respectively.
Thus, (a) is correct for both 100 and 10000 draws, since the quoted ranges are the expected values of the draws plus or minus the SEs.

(b) is based on the idea of using a normal approximation. When you draw 10,000 times, this normal approximation is reasonable, since the expected number of draws is so large. But when you draw only 100 times, the expected number of draws is too small to use the normal approximation. So for 100 draws, (b) is false, but for 10000 draws, (b) is true.
Please grade this question out of six points. Award one point each for getting each of the four parts correct, and award the remaining two points for correct explainations

question.p: NAEP (National Assessment of Educational Progress) periodically tests scientific knowledge in U.S. schools. Here is one question on the test, administered to students in grade 12.
question.blockquote: The diagram below shows a thermometer. On the diagram, fill in the thermometer so that it reads 37.5 degrees Celsius.
question.p: Only 64% of the students who were tested could answer this question correctly. The superintendent of education in a certain state cannot believe these data. To check, he takes a simple random sample of 100 high schools in the state, and tests 10 randomly selected students from grade 12 in each school. 661 out of the 1,000 students who take the test, or 66.1%, can do the problem. With the information above, can you put a standard error on the 66.1%? Find the SE, or say why this can't be done.

solution.p: This can't be done with the information given, because it is a cluster sample. That is, the 1,000 students' answers to the question are not independent, since some of them came from the same school and thus are likely to have been educated similarly. The following is not part of the question asked (and thus not worth any points), but is also worth noting. Since the superintendent only sampled students from his state, even if he did somehow obtain a sample of independent students and thus could compute a SE and thus a confidence interval for his estimate, that confidence interval would only apply within his state. Therefore he couldn't really compare it to the (presumably national) figure of 64%.
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.

ul.li: 3 points for saying the SE cannot be computed
3 points for stating that it is a cluster sample, or explaining why the observations aren't independent
Feel free to give partial credit or to use your good judgement if you think the case merits it

question.p: It has been said for many years (or even decades) that there is not much dating going on at Stanford. Some time ago the Stanford Daily did a study to find out the truth. Read the article "Sex on the Farm" by Ben Friedland. The article describes a survey and concludes that there is an active dating scene at Stanford. Does the survey indeed disprove the myth?

solution.p: The Daily interviewed students who happened to pass by White Plaza. This is a sample of convenience, not a random sample. Therefore, there is selection bias. For example, studious students may not be walking around White Plaza as much, and these students may also date less. There may also be some response bias because students are more likely to exaggerate their romantic life. Because the sample is not representative of the population, this survey does not disprove the myth.

Please grade this question out of six points. Award three points each for pointing out that there could be substantial selection bias and response bias, and for offering plausible guesses for how they would affect the results.
